channel.title: NYT > Science
channel.copyright: Copyright 2026 The New York Times Company

item.title: 430,000-Year-Old Wooden Tools Are the Oldest Ever Found
item.description: The finding, along with the discovery of a 500,000-year-old hammer made of bone, indicates that our human ancestors were making tools even earlier than archaeologists thought.
item.dc:creator: Franz Lidz

item.title: A New Way to Flirt: Dazzle Potential Mates With Patterns Invisible to Humans
item.description: Cuttlefish attract prospective sexual partners by creating a pattern on their skin, based on the orientation of light waves.
item.dc:creator: Kate Golembiewski
item.category: Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences

item.title: Sonic Booms and Seismic Waves Can Reveal Where Space Junk Crash-Lands
item.description: The sensors used to listen for earthquakes could help protect people from the hazards created by falling spacecraft.
item.dc:creator: Robin George Andrews

item.title: Genetic Data From Over 20,000 U.S. Children Misused for ‘Race Science’
item.description: The National Institutes of Health failed to protect brain scans that an international group of fringe researchers used to argue for the intellectual superiority of white people.
item.dc:creator: Mike McIntire

item.title: How to Cut an Infinitely Large Pancake into as Many Pieces as Possible
item.description: A team of mathematicians seeks to cut an infinitely large pancake into as many pieces as possible, in a new take on an old puzzle.
item.dc:creator: Siobhan Roberts

item.title: Thing-Like Robotic Hand Makes Life Resemble ‘The Addams Family’
item.description: The very capable robotic picker-upper can grasp things on both sides and roam around freely.
item.dc:creator: Ari Daniel

item.title: Filoplumes Are Nature’s Super Feather
item.description: Filoplumes may be tiny, but these hairlike feathers enable nonstop flights that span thousands of miles.
item.dc:creator: Jim Robbins and Bryan Anselm
item.media:credit: Bryan Anselm for The New York Times

item.title: A Bite-Size Column About Delight and Wonder in Science
item.description: In Trilobites, reporters aim to share new findings in the science world, be it interspecies friendships or discoveries of ancient fossils.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Ewing

item.title: Cows Use Tools, Too, New Study Finds
item.description: A pet cow named Veronika can scratch her own back with a broom — the first scientifically documented case of tool use in cows, researchers say.
item.dc:creator: Emily Anthes

item.title: Thomas Fogarty, 91, Who Helped Revolutionize Vascular Surgery, Dies
item.description: Drawing on his love of fly-fishing, he developed a balloon catheter that removes blood clots from patients’ limbs in a minimally invasive way. It has saved millions of lives.
item.dc:creator: Jeré Longman
item.media:description: Dr. Thomas J. Fogarty in 2000 on receiving the Lemelson-M.I.T. Prize for his work in developing medical technologies. He “single-handedly changed the face of cardiovascular surgery,” a colleague said.

item.title: William H. Foege, Key Figure in the Eradication of Smallpox, Dies at 89
item.description: His containment strategy helped wipe out the disease in the 1970s, one of the world’s greatest public health triumphs. He also led the C.D.C. and promoted childhood vaccination worldwide.
item.dc:creator: Keith Schneider and Sheryl Gay Stolberg
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:description: William H. Foege in 1985. He played a critical role in making smallpox the first infectious disease to be altogether eliminated. He stood beside a bust of Hygeia, the Greek goddess of health, at C.D.C. headquarters in Atlanta.

item.title: Is Climate Change Weakening the Polar Vortex?
item.description: Rising Arctic temperatures and melting sea ice could be causing cold air to flow into the Northern Hemisphere. But not all scientists agree.
item.dc:creator: Eric Niiler
item.media:credit: Jalen Wright for The New York Times
item.media:description: A study found that the stretching of the polar vortex was linked to increased severe winter weather in the United States in the past decade.

item.title: Edith Flanigen, Award-Winning Research Chemist, Dies at 96
item.description: She and her staff at Union Carbide created synthetic materials that improved various industrial processes, including purifying water. She also developed a way to make emeralds.
item.dc:creator: Richard Sandomir
item.media:credit: Alan Zale for The New York Times
item.media:description: Edith Flanigen in 1990. Ms. Flanigen was so widely respected that “when she walked into a room of senior management at Union Carbide, they would all stand up,” a former colleague said.

item.title: Pedro Sanchez, Who Helped Feed the Developing World, Dies at 85
item.description: A soil scientist, he partnered with the United Nations and other organizations to bring productive agricultural practices to uncooperative terrain.
item.dc:creator: Trip Gabriel

item.title: Louis E. Brus, Nobel Laureate Who Illuminated the Nanoworld, Dies at 82
item.description: He accidentally created some of the first quantum dots, tiny semiconductors that now power many electronics.
item.dc:creator: Katrina Miller
item.media:description: Louis E. Brus in 2023. “The entire field of nanoscience and nanotechnology owes a huge debt to him,” said Moungi Bawendi, a chemist who shared the Nobel Prize with Dr. Brus and Aleksey Yekimov.

item.title: Vaccine Panel Chair Says Polio and Other Shots Should Be Optional, Rejecting Decades of Science
item.description: Dr. Kirk Milhoan, a pediatric cardiologist who leads the Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices, said a person’s right to refuse a vaccine outweighed concerns about illness or death from infectious diseases.
item.dc:creator: Apoorva Mandavilli
item.media:description: Dr. Kirk Milhoan, a pediatric cardiologist who leads the Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices, speaking at a meeting of the committee in Chamblee, Ga., in September.

item.title: Increased Scrutiny Leads to an Improved Organ Transplant System
item.description: A crackdown on problems with fairness and safety is achieving results, including a big drop in the number of sick patients being passed over for transplants.
item.dc:creator: Brian M. Rosenthal
item.media:credit: Alyssa Schukar for The New York Times
item.media:description: A medical worker holding a recovered kidney.

item.title: An Antarctic Mission to Recover a Robot’s Data
item.description: In the unforgiving polar wilderness, scientists go to great lengths to safeguard the devices that gather precious data.
item.dc:creator: Raymond Zhong
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times

item.title: Big Insurers Try to Shift Blame for High Health Costs to Hospitals and Drug Makers
item.description: At two congressional hearings, lawmakers slammed executives of major companies, saying they were failing to rein in the cost of medical care for consumers.
item.dc:creator: Reed Abelson
item.category: Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)
Blue Cross and Blue Shield Assn
item.media:description: Stephen Hemsley, chief executive of UnitedHealth Group, left, defended insurers’ practices, along with other companies’ executives, during congressional hearings on Thursday.

item.title: RFK Jr. Plan to Test a Vaccine in West African Babies Is Blocked
item.description: A planned U.S.-funded study of a hepatitis B vaccine drew widespread condemnation from researchers. Now the host country says it cannot proceed.
item.dc:creator: Stephanie Nolen and Christina Jewett
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:description: Each year thousands of babies born in Guinea-Bissau, one of the world’s least developed countries, are exposed to hepatitis B, a virus that can cause severe liver damage and cancer.

item.title: Energy Dept. Says It Is Canceling $30 Billion in Clean Energy Loans
item.description: Many of the cancellations had been known for months, but the announcement underscored the drastic change in the energy landscape under President Trump.
item.dc:creator: Brad Plumer
item.media:credit: Callaghan O'Hare for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Energy Department canceled a partial loan guarantee to Sunnova Energy, a residential solar panel installer that was experimenting with a novel way to link home solar and battery systems.

item.title: Trump Administration Cuts Off Funding for Fetal Tissue Research. Again.
item.description: The prohibition halts support for projects both inside and outside the N.I.H. President Biden had restored funding after an earlier ban by President Trump during his first term.
item.dc:creator: Roni Caryn Rabin
item.media:description: Dr. Jay Bhattacharya, the N.I.H. director, said that the agency will look to make additional investments in “validated emerging technologies” that could “reduce or potentially replace reliance on human embryonic stem cells.”

item.title: A 67,800-Year-Old Handprint May Be the World’s Oldest Rock Art
item.description: “It was hiding in plain sight all this time,” one researcher said.
item.dc:creator: Claire Moses and Yan Zhuang

item.title: Some Immune Systems Defeat Cancer. Could That Become a Drug?
item.description: Researchers found an antibody that seems to play a role in people with better lung cancer prognoses, but turning it into a treatment could be difficult.
item.dc:creator: Gina Kolata

item.title: Rising Global Temperatures May Affect Choices for Winter Olympic Venues
item.description: Future games will need to be held at higher altitudes, and spread over multiple venues in order to adapt to a changing climate, new research suggests.
item.dc:creator: Eric Niiler
item.media:description: Gus Schumacher, a member of the U.S. cross-country skiing team, left, competing in Planica, Slovenia, in March 2023.

item.title: What’s a Human Life Worth? The E.P.A. Says Zero Dollars.
item.description: The Environmental Protection Agency has stopped estimating the dollar value of lives saved in the cost-benefit analyses for new pollution rules.
item.dc:creator: Maxine Joselow
item.category: Office of Information and Regulatory Affairs (US)
item.media:description: Los Angeles smog in 1979. For decades, government agencies have used a theoretical value of human life when calculating the costs and benefits of new regulations.

item.title: Scientists Set Up Camp on Thwaites Glacier in Antarctica
item.description: Low clouds have lifted long enough for helicopters to ferry scientists and their gear to a fast-melting glacier on the edge of Antarctica.
item.dc:creator: Raymond Zhong
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times

item.title: Democrats Seek Investigation of $3.5 Million Deal by Interior Official’s Husband
item.description: Records show that Karen Budd-Falen, a top Interior Department official, didn’t disclose a contract between her husband and the developers of a mine approved by the agency.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Friedman
item.media:description: Karen Budd-Falen in 2017. Ms. Budd-Falen, currently the third-ranking official at the Interior Department, also worked at the agency during the first Trump administration.

item.title: Will ‘Psychiatry’s Bible’ Add a Postpartum Psychosis Diagnosis?
item.description: Leaders of the D.S.M., the world’s most influential psychiatric manual, have been split for more than five years over whether to recognize postpartum psychosis as a distinct disorder.
item.dc:creator: Ellen Barry and Pam Belluck
item.category: Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders (Book)
item.media:credit: Alycee Byrd for The New York Times
item.media:description: Emily Swilinski of Greensboro, N.C., did not have a history of mental health issues when, after giving birth to her first child, she suddenly had racing thoughts, trouble sleeping, and began hallucinating that her dog was speaking to her.
